awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: New models and techniques for efficient communication in smartphone ad-hoc networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop two new smartphone-based infrastructure models to support applications that require interaction and communication in the proximity without the support of the Internet. It is motivated by the fact that ad-hoc networks formed by a collection of smartphones can help improve the current location-based services, propel new applications, and enhance the wireless infrastructures. In this project, one model harnesses the heterogeneous radio interfaces to improve bulk data transfer while the other model explores a new passive communication approach for disseminating short messages such as Tweets and Facebook messages. Both new models target on reducing the energy cost and network overhead which are critical to deploying smartphone ad-hoc networks. If successful, this project will result in two new mobile ad-hoc network architectures and a suite of protocols built on them. It is expected to have immediate impact on the research community and industry. The results of this project will further broaden the mobile application scope and may inspire developers to create innovative services based on local data communication.

Specifically, this project addresses the high-cost issue in path establishment and path recovery in traditional mobile ad-hoc networks. The first new model integrates a long-range radio into a smartphone to carry out control and management packets while payload data are still transferred over regular radios such as WiFi and Bluetooth. A new routing protocol will be developed based on this dual radio setting to improve the efficiency. The second new model uses the mandatory 'peer discovery' function in Bluetooth and WiFi-Direct protocols to disseminate short messages among the smartphones in the proximity. The cost for establishing and maintaining wireless links is negligible, and the feature of fetching messages from multiple nearby devices is desirable for the applications that spread messages in the proximity. This project will develop an appropriate strategy for each smartphone to receive and dispatch messages with the objective of conserving the energy cost and improving the message delivery ratio.

por.por_cntn:
Smartphones have revolutionized computing, making them one of the most groundbreaking devices in history. Their prevalence has expanded the scope of smartphone applications, covering various aspects of our daily lives. This project focuses on developing two efficient communication models for smartphone ad-hoc networks, aiming to achieve effective communication in proximity without infrastructure support. These models can enhance location-based services, introduce new applications, and improve wireless infrastructures.

1. The first model, called the long-range radio assisted communication model, involves integrating an additional long-range radio transceiver into smartphones to aid Mobile Ad-hoc Network routing. In our project, we have integrated a long-range but low-rate radio into smartphones for control and management messages, while data communication still relies on WiFi or Bluetooth. We have developed a suite of routing protocols based on this new radio hardware and conducted extensive experiments using our prototypes, demonstrating significant performance improvements.

2. The second model, known as passive delivery, eliminates the need for route establishment. In this model, each sender buffers its data locally, and the receiver initiates the transmission. Periodically, each node scans other nodes within its communication range and retrieves available data from their buffers. Bluetooth and WiFi-Direct are representative examples of passive delivery carriers, as they include a mandatory "peer discovery" function to fetch basic information about nearby devices, such as device name and MAC address. This function can be easily extended to implement a passive delivery mechanism without modifying the existing network protocol stack. In our project, we utilize the "device name" field to carry payload data and have developed a local data dissemination system for gossip-style communication. Our target applications include spreading messages like announcements, warnings, and tweets in proximity, as well as enabling local instant messaging.

3. In addition to the two communication models, our project explores several new applications based on the ad-hoc network framework. We have investigated the following applications:

a. Mobile Message Board: This message dissemination system, based on the passive delivery model, maintains announced messages within a specific region in an ad-hoc network formed by mobile users. The goal is to keep the messages alive or available for as long as possible within the region, so that users can access all the previously posted information when browsing the virtual message board. We have developed a solution based on the passive delivery model that maximizes the message delivery ratio while keeping communication costs low.

b. Big Data Processing on IoT Devices: Our investigation focuses on big data processing platforms, such as Hadoop and Spark, running on a cluster of IoT devices. We recognize that the computational capabilities of IoT devices have improved with advancements in hardware. Leveraging the ad-hoc communication model, we have further improved wireless communication by understanding specific data transfer patterns in big data processing applications.

c. Computer Vision Applications: We explore two computer vision-related applications. The first is exact scene recognition, enabling users to recognize the same scene by sharing and comparing image features. We have developed techniques to identify 'blocked' feature points and improve accuracy. The second application involves multi-user augmented reality (AR), allowing virtual objects placed by one user to be viewed by others. Our practical framework supports basic multi-user AR functions on off-the-shelf smartphones, addressing challenges related to varying view angles and distances.

As a result of this project, we have published five research papers and presented one poster at premium conferences, including IEEE INFOCOM, IEEE Cloud, ICNC, and ACM SOSP. These research results have been disseminated in conferences and other academic events attended by the Principal Investigator (PI) and the participating students.

A total of five Ph.D. students, one master's student, and two undergraduate students have contributed to this project, including one female student and one U.S. veteran. Their involvement has provided them with valuable experiences in algorithm analysis, performance modeling, system implementation/testing, and emerging technologies in the field of wireless networks, mobile computing, and the Internet of Things. Four of the Ph.D. students have successfully graduated, with three of them securing tenure-track assistant professor positions at four-year colleges. The U.S. veteran student initially joined the project as an undergraduate and, motivated by the experiences gained, decided to pursue a Master's degree while continuing to contribute as a graduate student.

The PI has incorporated project materials into two courses, namely "Computer Networks" and "Wireless Networks and Mobile Computing," to motivate students and demonstrate state-of-the-art techniques. This integration has contributed to the improvement of STEM education, providing students with practical applications and hands-on experiences.

Overall, this project has made significant contributions to the field of smartphone ad-hoc networks by developing efficient communication models and exploring new applications. Moreover, it has empowered the participating students, enhanced STEM education, and fostered advancements in wireless networks, mobile computing, and the Internet of Things.
